modules.description: This module manages in-memory caches of network link objects using C-compatible pointers. It provides operations to iterate over cached entries, convert caches to lists of pointers, and free allocated cache memory. Concrete use cases include inspecting or manipulating network interface state from low-level networking tools.

This module manages network interface addresses using Netlink. It provides functions to allocate and iterate over address caches, extract interface indices, labels, and local addresses from Netlink address structures. Concrete use cases include retrieving and processing IP address information for network interfaces.

This module provides low-level operations for creating, connecting, and managing Netlink sockets, specifically for communication with the kernel using protocols like NETLINK_ROUTE. It works with C-style structures and pointers to handle socket resources and protocol conversions. Concrete use cases include establishing a connection to the Linux kernel for routing and network device management via Netlink messages.

This module provides functions to interact with network link devices using Netlink sockets. It supports retrieving and caching link information such as interface index, name, MTU, MAC address, and packet statistics like received and transmitted bytes or errors. Use cases include monitoring network interface performance, querying interface properties, and managing link state in low-level networking tools.

This module enables low-level network configuration and monitoring through direct interaction with Netlink sockets, combining core utilities for address manipulation, type conversion, and handling nullable values via Ctypes. It centers around data types like `addr` and integrates with system libraries to manage network interfaces, routing tables, and socket communication. The `Socket` submodule handles kernel-level Netlink connections, while `Cache` and `Address` provide in-memory representations and IP address management for network link objects. Use cases include querying interface statistics, modifying routing entries, and inspecting network device properties through structured Netlink messages.
